name: Tasks - High impact tasks (by component)

ox.label: Task
ox.filter: count files for commits >= 50 and commits >= 3

notes: Analyse the impact of scattered tasks. Do they affect multiple components (in which case they could increase the team's cognitive load)? Does implementing tasks require changes to components owned by different teams (in which case they would require high coordination costs?

name: Task prefixes - Files (by repo) and commits

oy1.query: count files for commits not having taskprefix.@
oy1.label: Files (w. task references in commits)

notes: Get an overview of task prefixes and their usage across the various repositories

name: Repositories (by task prefixes) - by change
notes: What is the relation between repositories and task prefixes? Are task prefixes used across repositories?

name: Repositories (by task prefixes)
notes: What is the relation between repositories and task prefixes? Are task prefixes used across repositories?

name: Languages - Overall and recent activity

oy1.label: Source-files (in red files changed last year)

oy2.query: count files having (technology.code and first change during last year)
oy2.label: Source-files created last year

notes: What are the filetypes that concentrate most of the recent changes? Is the ratio of recently changed files over all files consistent across technologies or is there a filetype that has been changed disproportionally (e.g. changes across most of the js files, perhaps signaling a major framework version upgrade)?

name: Filetypes (by creation year)
notes: Understand the main technologies used in the project. The file creation year can help you understand the phase of development. We also recommend grouping by latestChangeYear, to understand the change patterns.

name: Filetypes (by component)
notes: Understand in what component each technology is used.

name: Files - Active knowledge on complexity hotspots

ox.filter: sum strength of metric.atc >= 1 and changes >= 20 and size >= 500

oy1.query: ((sum churn of changes for authors having (status.active and name not starts with _)) * 100) / (sum churn of changes for authors having name not starts with _)
oy1.label: % Activity volume by currently active developers

notes: Does the current team have enough experience on the most complex files?

name: Evolution - Growth of code vs growth of complexity hotspots

oy1.query: sum size of files having technology.code
oy1.label: Size of code

oy2.query: sum size of files having (technology.code and strength of metric.atc >= 1 and changes >= 20 and size >= 500)
oy2.label: Size of complexity hotspots

notes: How does the growth of the complexity hotsptos compare with the overall source-code growth?

oy1.label: Commits (in red commits on complexiity hotspots)
oy1.highlight: has file having (sum strength of metric.atc >= 1 and changes >= 20 and size >= 500)

oy2.query: (count commits for files having (technology.code and strength of metric.atc >= 1 and changes >= 20 and size >= 500) * 100) / (count commits)
oy2.label: % Commits on complexity hotspots

name: Evolution - Change volume on complexity hotspots

oy1.query: sum churn of changes for files having technology.code
oy1.label: Volume of change (in red changes on complexity hotspots)
oy1.highlight: has file having (sum strength of metric.atc >= 1 and changes >= 20 and size >= 500)

oy2.query: ((sum churn of changes for files having (technology.code and strength of metric.atc >= 1 and changes >= 20 and size >= 500)) * 100) / (sum churn of changes for files having technology.code)
oy2.label: % Change on complexity hotspots

notes: This chart helps to see how much of the volume of change is in the complexity hotspots

name: Evolution - Task prefixes
notes: How has the usage of task prefixes evolved? This can correlate to changes in project priorities (e.g if there is a task prefixes per product). This could also indicate a team with a high cognitive load that is spread too thin (e.g. working on many projects/task prefixes in parallel).

name: Evolution - Periodic growth (by repo) and overall size - changes

oy1.query: sum growth of changes for commits having growth > 0
oy1.label: Sum growth of changes for commits

notes: You can spot: (1) how old the codebase is; (2) the oldest and newest repos; (3) the repos with the highest recent growth, and repos that are inactive; (4) months with abrupt growth; (5) periods of standstill. Based on the duration of the project and the growth patterns you can get a solid indication on the project's current development phase: has the project started recently? or is it in vibrant growth? or in consolidation phase? or in maintenance? or close to standstill?

name: Evolution - Periodic growth (by repo) and overall size -

oy1.query: sum growth of commits having growth > 0
oy1.label: Growth (by repository)

notes: You can spot: (1) how old the codebase is; (2) the oldest and newest repos; (3) the repos with the highest recent growth, and repos that are inactive; (4) months with abrupt growth; (5) periods of standstill. Based on the duration of the project and the growth patterns you can get a solid indication on the project's current development phase: has the project started recently? or is it in vibrant growth? or in consolidation phase? or in maintenance? or close to standstill?

name: Evolution - New files with code duplication (by changes)

oy1.query: count files having (anomaly.*Dup* and first change during period)
oy1.label: New files with duplication (by changes)

notes: This view can help you understand if duplication is systematic and if it's an ongoing practice. For example, are new duplicate files created every year? Do they evolve after they are initially developed?

name: Evolution - New developers joining

oy1.query: count authors having (commits during period and not name starts with _)
oy1.label: All Developers (in red new developers)

notes: What's the ratio of new developers to existing developers? Is there a constant flux of new developers? Was there a complete team swap?

name: Evolution - Developers joining and leaving

oy1.query: count authors having (first commit during period and not name starts with _)
oy1.label: Developers joining

oy2.query: count authors having (last commit during period and not name starts with _)
oy2.label: Developers leaving

notes: Look at the pattern of developers joining and leaving. Disregard at least the last 2-3 month.

name: Evolution - Last year changes (by creation year)
notes: This view helps you see if over the last year the files that were under active development represent new code, or changes to old files. This in turn helps you understand what type of development activity is happening.

name: Evolution - Files (test versus production)

oy1.query: count files having technology.code for changes
oy1.label: Source-files (by role)

notes: Is the number of changed test files proportional to changed production files? Are test files updated each month or in batches? This indicates if automated testing is part of daily development work or something done infrequently.

name: Evolution - Files (by technology)
notes: If the codebase uses many technologies, this view helps you spot any change in development patterns (e.g. from code to web). Use the principle of surprise (e.g. are there many configuration files updated each month?).

name: Evolution - Developers (by overall contribution)

oy1.query: count authors having not name starts with _ for commits
oy1.label: Developers

notes: Are there "satellite" developers that make few overall changes? If there are many such developers, the conceptual integrity of the code base could suffer.

name: Evolution - Developers (by monthly pace)

oy1.query: count authors having not name starts with _ for commits
oy1.label: Developers (by commits during month)

notes: This view is useful when there are many developers with few monthly commits. This low level of involvement raises the potential risk that it will take a long time for developers to become proficient on the codebase.

name: Evolution - Commits (smart and literate fractions)
notes: Is the team consistently using smart commits and literate commits?

name: Evolution - Commits (by weekday)
notes: Is the team frequently committing during weekends? Is the team frequently committing more at the end of the sprint (e.g. on Fridays) - this could lead to a drop in code quality.

name: Evolution - Commits (by repo) and developers - changes

oy1.query: count commits having author having not name starts with _ for changes
oy1.label: Commits (by repository)

oy2.query: count authors having not name starts with _ for commits
oy2.label: Developers

notes: Is there any correlation between the number of developers and the number of commits (or churn) over the codebase's history?

name: Evolution - Commits (by repo) and developers

oy1.query: count commits having author having not name starts with _
oy1.label: Commits (by repository)

oy2.query: count authors having not name starts with _ for commits
oy2.label: Developers

notes: Is there any correlation between the number of developers and the number of commits (or churn) over the codebase's history?

name: Evolution - Commits by changes (by repo)
notes: This shows the activity timeline using commits. Used together with Growth and Churn charts, to understand the codebase's history.

name: Evolution - Commits (by repo)
notes: This shows the activity timeline using commits. Used together with Growth and Churn charts, to understand the codebase's history.

name: Evolution - Commits (by part-of-day)
notes: Is there a significant number of commits outside of working hours? What's the pattern (e.g., constant, every X months, sporadic)? Does it correlate with any important events (e.g. big release, started working from home because of Covid)?

name: Evolution - Commits (by geozone)
notes: This chart helps you understand where is the team based. Was there a switch from one geozone to another? Are commits from two geozones done at the same time?

name: Evolution - Commits (by developer's project influence)
notes: Is there a large percentage of commits done by developers with a weak involvement (i.e. less than 20 commits) in the codebase (up to that point)?

name: Evolution - Commits (by developer tenure)

oy1.query: count commits having author having not name starts with _
oy1.label: Commits (by developers' tenure)

notes: The view helps to spot (at least) the following patterns: (1) periods with spikes in the number of active developers; (2) the balance between devs who worked longer on the project (veteran, senior) versus those who started working more recently (established, newcomer). Regarding the second point, check if in the latest months there is a trend of newer devs dominating the activity, while more experience devs slowing down. Note that the activity status is dynamic: in their first months of activity developers developers are 'newcomers', and over time they switch their status. Therefore, in the first months of the project all developers working on the project are 'newcomers'. Also check to see if (1) is there constant on-boarding of new developers? (2) has the team completely changed over its history? (3) is there a significant drop in the number of commits made by experienced developers?

name: Evolution - Commits (by change volume)
notes: The view indicates the number of commits, in order to see how many bulk commits are done monthly. Remember that 'bulk commits' refers to those commits with a very large change-set or a very large volume of change.

name: Evolution - Code churn (by change volume)
notes: The view indicates the impact that bulk commits have on the overall volume of change per month. Remember that 'bulk commits' refers to those commits with a very large change-set or a very large volume of change.

name: Evolution - Changes (by file role) and bug-fixing rate
notes: How has the Bug-fix percentage evolved over time? Does this correlate with an increase/decrease in test code changes?

name: Evolution - Changes (by component) and overall size
notes:
How has the codebase grown over time: (i) is there a low or a high growth rate? (ii) has the growth rate changed over the codebase's history (e.g. signaling a change from development to maintenance)? 
NOTE: Look for extremely high growth in a single period. This can signal an import event, which could be marked on the chart.

name: Evolution - Change volume per developer

oy1.query: (sum churn of commits not having (volume.*.bulk or volume.*.import)) / (count authors for commits not having (volume.*.bulk or volume.*.import))
oy1.label: Churn / Dev (only non-bulk commits)

oy2.query: (sum growth of commits not having (volume.*.bulk or volume.*.import)) / (count authors for commits not having (volume.*.bulk or volume.*.import))
oy2.label: Growth / Dev (only non-bulk commits)

notes: Many times, the output per developer decreases as the time evolves (because of the increasing technical debt and architecture viscosity). Is this the case here? Were there any software modernisation efforts? Did they pay off (note: many times modernisation efforts make things worse before they get better, so be sure to look over a longer time horizon)

name: Developers - Recent files (by language) and code churn

ox.label: Developer
ox.filter: not name starts with _ and changes during last 2 years for files having technology.code

oy1.query: sum size of files for changes having (date during last 2 years and files having technology.code)
oy1.label: Sum size of files for changes

oy2.query: sum churn of changes during last 2 years for files having technology.code
oy2.label: Sum churn of changes for files

notes: This view aims at estimating the cognitive load of developers: How much code do they need understand in order to make a change?

name: Developers - Commits (by task prefix)
notes: How are task prefixes assigned to developers/teams?

name: Developers - Commits for changes (by repos)
notes: Do developers work across repositories? Are there any repositories with polarised ownership? Are the most prolific developers still active?

name: Developers - Commits (by repos)
notes: Do developers work across repositories? Are there any repositories with polarised ownership? Are the most prolific developers still active?

name: Developers - Volume of change (by technology)

oy1.query: sum churn of changes not having language.@
oy1.label: Volume of change (by technology)

notes: Are developers full-stack? Or is there a clear separation between backend/frontend/test/infrastructure/db? If developers work across technologies, is there a preferred tech per developer or is it evenly spread? Also, if they do work across languages, investigate if this is a requirement (i.e. is there strong task or co-change coupling between files/components from different languages)?

name: Developers - Volume of Change (by component)
notes: Do developers work across components? Are there any components with polarised ownership? Are the most prolific developers still active?

name: Concepts by component
notes: Are important concepts spread over many components?

name: Components - Weak ownership files (by last change)

oy1.label: Source-files with weak ownership (by year of last change)

notes: Are there many recently changed files with Weak Ownership? This poses the risk that the team does not have enough knowledge of these files, which in turn may lead to slower and more error-prone changes

name: Components - Dormant code fraction

oy2.query: ((files having (not changes during last 2 years and technology.code)) * 100) / (count files having technology.code)
oy2.label: % Files unchanged for at least 2 years

notes: What are the components with the highest percentage of dormant code? Components that are completely dormant are less of an issue, since the data shows that there is a low probability of needing to change them. Notice components where a high percentage of code is dormant (e.g., over 95%), since changing them could be risky.

name: Components (by main geozone)

oy1.label: Filles (by main region where it was developed)

notes: Is a component developed in two Geozones? This can be problematic, as syncing across timezones is more difficult and the preferred approach is for a team to fully own a component.

name: Code Anomalies (by repository)
notes: What are the most widespread anomalies? What repositories to they affect?

name: Evolution - Deletes and Total size
notes: For this chart to work, make sure that the "Keep only alive files" checkbox in unchecked in config. This chart can help you investigate cases of deleted files. This is useful, for example, when checking if functionality has been migrated.
